awd_titl_txt: Using genetic and computational methods to investigate morphological variation
awd_abstract_narration:
This research examines environmental and genetic factors that influence body size and shape in humans. The project compares genetic variation, body size measurements, and environmental measurements of ancient people to advance knowledge about human adaptation and the relative roles of genetic and environmental factors affecting human morphology. The project supports a post-doctoral researcher to develop quantitative and computational research skills that are necessary to analyze these data, as well as national and international collaborations. The results of this research are used to develop museum exhibits and teaching materials that support public and K-12 science education and outreach.

Changes in human body size can be assessed by measuring the skeletons of ancient individuals. However, these data reflect only the cumulative effects of both genetics and environment. Recent advances in genetic technology make it possible to sequence ancient genomes and make direct estimates of the genetic contribution to height. It is also possible to collect some information about the environment in which ancient individuals lived through methods such as stable isotope analysis. This project collates a large dataset of genetic, phenotypic and archaeological measurements and develops statistical models to combine these different types of data and identify the relative importance of different factors. By separating genetic and environmental factors it is possible to determine whether changes in body size and shape are driven by plastic developmental response to environmental change, genetic changes, or both. As well as addressing these questions about the human form, the research can provide a roadmap for integrating ancient genetic data with other anthropological measurements like markers of health and disease. Finally, data collated as part of the research are made publicly available as a resource for further studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first goal of this project was to establish whether we could use genetic data from ancient DNA to predict the stature of ancient humans. We collected data from over 500 ancient individuals mostly from West Eurasia from the past 10,000 years who had both stature estimates (based on femur length), and whole-genome genetic data available. We then carefully evaluated different methods of stature prediction based on large-scale genetic studies of present-day people (genome-wide association studies, or GWAS). We used two statistical metrics to evaluate performance and compare different predictors. First, how much of the variance in stature could be explained by the genetic predictor, and second, how unbiased it is relative to present-day genetic variation. In particular, because our samples largely come from West Eurasia, GWAS carried out in populations of European ancestry are likely to explain more variance, but also to be biased. We developed and optimized a bioinformatic pipeline for prediction and identified two optimal predictors: one that maximizes variance explained and one that maximizes variance explained but is also unbiased. We also found that these predictors were more accurate in males than females, suggesting a greater environmental contribution to female stature (compared to males) in prehistoric times. 

 

The second goal of the project was to use this genetic predictor to answer questions about the effect of changes in environment and culture on stature (and general health) of ancient populations. This goal had two parts. First, we asked whether agricultural populations were shorter than expected given these genetic predictors. This question has been difficult to address before because of the issues with confounding in GWAS described above. By using the optimal unbiased predictor, we can address this question robustly. We find that Early Farming populations in Europe (8,000-6,000 years ago) were shorter than we would have expected based on genetics, suggesting that the health effects of early agriculture were negative compared to their hunter-gatherer predecessors. However, later agricultural populations were substantially taller and close to genetic expectations suggesting that, as agricultural technology developed after about 5,000 years ago, the negative effects of early agriculture were ameliorated. Second, we asked whether factors other than genetics or environment (particularly agriculture) could moderate stature. We showed that within early agricultural populations (8,000-6,000 years ago), the difference between male and female stature was highly variable across populations. In particular, male stature was relatively consistent, but in groups in present-day Northern Germany, female stature was extremely low. This difference could not be explained by genetics and not solely by environment (which would be expected to affect males as much as females). We concluded that the negative effects of environment in this population were experienced disproportionately by females, likely reflecting a cultural preference for males in times of environmental stress. 

 

In summary, this project led to the development and validation of statistical and bioinformatic approaches to predict phenotypes in ancient populations from genetic data. And, as an application, demonstrated the existence of sex-based biological inequality in Stone Age Europe. In a broader sense, this provides one example of how cultural factors can have real biological impact on health and wellbeing in human populations, something that is relevant for understanding social determinants of health today.
